Projects

Laminar Flow Fountain 4 Arduino C, Solidworks, Fritzing Principles of Engineering (Olin Course)

Smooth Streams and Blinky Lights

This project was the culminating experience of Principles of Engineering, which requires final projects to include non-trivial mechanical, electronic, and software components. My team's goal was to create a miniature Bellagio-style fountain with laminar flow nozzles and with RGB LED's driven by a filtered audio signal. My primary responsibilities were designing the circuitry and implementing the signal filtering. The full project page for the Fountain can be found here!

MendelMax 2.0 Build 1 SolidWorks Personal Project

An Exercise in Frugality

While shopping around for 3D printers, I stumbled upon the MendelMax series, which all have open-sourced hardware. I am currently working towards building a custom, self-sourced MendelMax 2.0. So far I have both a BOM with costs of components and a 3D SolidWorks assembly. Check out the GrabCad project here!

Electric Go-kart 8 Welding, Mechanical Design, SolidWorks Research of Electrical Vehicles at Olin (REVO)

A Competitive Electric Vehicle

As a member of the chassis subteam, I worked on the design and fabrication of several mechanical components as well as the assembly of our team's electric go-kart. Check out the REVO site here!

Simple Single-cycle CPU 3 Verilog, ModelSim Computer Architecture (Olin Course)

A Working MIPS CPU in Verilog

Working with two other teammates, I helped to implement a complete single-cycle MIPS CPU in Verilog. The CPU was capable of taking compiled MARS assembly code and running 16 different instructions.

Survo 2 Node.js, MongoDB, Linode, HTML/CSS, Jquery Autonomous Humans Lab

A Web-app for Education Research

During the summer of 2013, I worked with a partner at the Autonomous Humans Lab of to create a web app that could automate the process of sending out a survey to a class over regular intervals of time. The app, Survo, is to be launched at several universities across the country this spring and can be found here!

RC Snake 5 Solidworks, Mechanical Design Design Nature (Olin College)

A Bio-inspired Toy for Fourth Graders

In Design Nature, we were tasked with creating a game for fourth graders which involved a bio-inspired toy. As a member of Team Snake, we designed a game where the children were divided into two teams. One team controlled four small chicks using which were moved using magnets attached to rods while the other team piloted a remote-controlled snake. The children controlling the chicks attempted to avoid the snake while the other children tried to eat the chicks.
